Before a swarm of cameras in the White House Rose Garden and with his wife and the president at his side, Vice President Joe Biden on Wednesday announced that he would not be running for the highest office in the nation – that he was out of time to run a successful campaign and the window “has closed.” With Biden out of the 2016 contest and his role as veep winding down, POLITICO takes a look at his decades-long career in politics and the policy he has shaped.

            By 
Diana D’Abruzzo

10/21/15 08:54 PM EDT
Then-Sen. Joe Biden waits to be interviewed by reporters following his speech on U.S. policy in Iraq in June 2005. Biden spent 36 years as a senator representing Delaware before moving on to the White House as the second-in-command.

                                                            Getty
Standing with his wife, Neilia (center), Biden carries sons Beau and Hunter during an appearance at Delaware's Democratic state convention in the summer of 1972, when he was running for the U.S. Senate. With them are Gov.-elect Sherman W. Tribbitt and his wife, Jeanne. Neilia and the Bidens' 1-year-old daughter, Naomi, were killed in a car crash months later on Dec. 20, 1972. 

                                                            AP Photo
Days before his 30th birthday, Biden won an upset victory to become the fifth-youngest U.S. senator elected in the nation's history. He is pictured in Washington on Dec. 12, 1972.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden (left) offers words of encouragement to his bedridden son, Beau, before being sworn in as senator in a ceremony at a Wilmington, Del., hospital on Jan. 5, 1973. At right, Biden's other son, Hunter, talks with Biden's father-in-law, Robert Hunter. Beau was still in traction from the car accident that killed his mother and sister.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden is pictured at the Capitol in February 1976.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden speaks at a Democratic Party event in Maine on May 7, 1976.

                                                            AP Photo
From left, Sens. George McGovern (D-S.D.), Dick Clark (D-Iowa) and Biden — members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee —huddle May 12, 1978, as they prepare to vote on the proposed sale of U.S. warplanes to countries in the Middle East. The panel later sent the full Senate a report making no recommendation for or against the sale. 

                                                            AP Photo
Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee — including Sens. Alan Simpson (R-Wyo.), Bob Dole (R-Kan.), Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) and Biden — confer Sept. 15, 1981, prior to voting to recommend the nomination of Supreme Court nominee Sandra Day O'Connor to the full Senate for confirmation.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden appears on NBC's "Face the Nation" on April 29, 1984.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden holds his daughter, Ashley, as he reenacts the taking of his oath of office Jan. 3, 1985, from Vice President George H.W. Bush. Biden's sons, Beau and Hunter, hold the Bible during the Capitol Hill ceremony.

                                                            AP Photo
On July 23, 1986, Biden tells the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and Secretary of State George Shultz that U.S. policy toward South Africa amounts to a shameful lack of backbone. Biden, in a sharp exchange with Shultz, said "blacks have tried everything available to them in the last 20 years," and nothing has worked. 

                                                            AP Photo
Soon after announcing his candidacy for president on June 9, 1987, Biden and his family — sons Beau and Hunter, daughter Ashley and wife Jill — wave from a train as they leave Wilmington, Del. “In this world, emotion has become suspect — the accepted style is smooth, antiseptic and passionless," the 44-year-old Biden told a crowd at the train station.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, holds up letters from law professors opposing the confirmation of Judge Robert Bork to the Supreme Court on Sept. 30, 1987.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden (third from right) joins his fellow Democratic candidates — Michael Dukakis, Dick Gephardt, Bruce Babbitt, Jesse Jackson, Al Gore and Paul Simon — at a presidential debate Sept. 11, 1987, at the University of North Carolina.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden, flanked by his wife, Jill, and daughter, Ashley, meets with reporters following his release from Walter Reed Army Medical Center on May 21, 1988. Biden underwent successful surgery earlier that month to correct an aneurysm near his brain. 

                                                            AP Photo
Supreme Court justice nominee Clarence Thomas laughs while talking with Sen. Strom Thurmond (R-S.C.), ranking Republican of the Senate Judiciary Committee, and Committee Chairman Biden on Sept. 10, 1991, prior to the start of Thomas' confirmation hearing. 

                                                            AP Photo
The mood was a little different two days later as Biden gestures while questioning Thomas on Capitol Hill. Thurmond is pictured at left.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden accompanies Janet Reno outside the White House on March 11, 1993, after a private meeting with President Bill Clinton. Unanimously confirmed by the Senate, Reno became the nation's first female attorney general. 

                                                            AP Photo
Biden stands in front of a Danish armored personnel carrier at the U.N.-controlled Sarajevo Airport in Bosnia on April 9, 1993.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden holds up an explosive device during a hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee on April 22, 1993. The committee was holding hearings on terrorism in the United States.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden holds a TEC-9 semi-automatic weapon during a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing Aug. 3, 1993, on combating the proliferation of assault weapons. 

                                                            AP Photo
Biden talks to reporters outside the White House after a luncheon between President Bill Clinton and Democratic senators on Feb. 10, 1995. 

                                                            AP Photo
President Bill Clinton talks with (from left) Senate Majority Leader Bob Dole, Sen. Orrin Hatch and Biden as he arrives at a signing ceremony for the Anti-Terrorism Bill on April 24, 1996. The legislation gave federal authorities $1 billion worth of additional tools to fight terrorism at home and abroad.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden speaks to South Korean President Kim Dae-Jung as Sen. Jesse Helms (R-N.C.) stands by during June 10, 1998, meetings with members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Kim saw his visit to the U.S. as an opportune moment for new paths to reconciliation with North Korea. 

                                                            AFP/Getty
Biden waves to spectators along the parade route for the St. Patrick's Day Parade in Manchester, N.H., on March 25, 2001. 

                                                            AP Photo
Biden (center) joins Sens. Ted Kennedy (D-Mass.) and Barbara Mikulski (D-Md.) in prayer with rescue workers amid the rubble of the destroyed World Trade Center in New York on Sept. 20, 2001. The three were part of a delegation of senators who traveled by train to New York following the terror attacks.
Biden is silhouetted next to an American flag in his office in the Russell Building on Capitol Hill on Oct. 25, 2001.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden talks with Afghans during a visit to the old Soviet Embassy compound in Kabul, where some 15,000 internally displaced Afghans live, on Jan. 11, 2002.  Biden was on a two-day visit to the Afghan capital.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden and Israel's Prime Minister Ariel Sharon (left) laugh during a meeting at the Capitol on June 11, 2002. Sharon was visiting Capitol Hill to thank members of both houses of Congress for their support for Israel and his policies. 

                                                            AFP/Getty
Biden stands with Democratic presidential candidate Sen. John Kerry during a campaign rally at the University of Pennsylvania on Sept. 24, 2004, in Philadelphia.  

                                                            AP Photo
Biden (right) and Sen. Richard Lugar (R-Ind.) listen as Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice testifies on President George W. Bush's 2006 budget for the State Department on Feb. 16, 2005.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden appears on a monitor during a remote interview on NBC's "Meet the Press" with moderator Andrea Mitchell (left) on Aug. 14, 2005. Biden talked about the situation with the war in Iraq. 

                                                            Getty
Biden jokingly wears a Princeton University cap during the third day of confirmation hearings Jan. 11, 2006, for U.S. Supreme Court nominee Judge Samuel Alito. Alito graduated from Princeton, but Biden's gesture was in reference to the judge's well-known dislike of the institution.

                                                            Getty
A decade after his first attempt, Biden ran for president again in 2007-2008. Here, Biden looks on as Sen. Hillary Clinton (D-N.Y.) speaks during the "All-American Presidential Forums on PBS" at Howard University on June 28, 2007.

                                                            Getty
Biden speaks with Iraqi and American officials during a visit to Ramadi, Iraq, on Sept. 6, 2007. 

                                                            Getty
Biden dropped out of the presidential contest in early 2008, but he'd be back on the trail soon enough. Above, a text message on Aug. 23, 2008, announces  Biden as Barack Obama's choice for running-mate.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden takes the stage on Aug. 23, 2008, in Springfield, Ill., as Obama's vice presidential running-mate.

                                                            AP Photo
Obama and Biden acknowledge their supporters on election night Nov. 4, 2008, in Chicago. Obama defeated Republican nominee Sen. John McCain by a wide margin in the election to become the first African-American president.

                                                            Getty
Vice President Biden talks with a group of Navy SEAL trainees during a visit to the Naval Amphibious Base Coronado in Coronado, Calif., on May 14, 2009. 

                                                            AP Photo
Biden (left) and Obama (right) have a beer with Harvard scholar Henry Louis Gates Jr. (second from left) and Cambridge, Mass., police Sgt. James Crowley in the Rose Garden on July 30, 2009. Gates was arrested after police responded to a report of a possible break-in at his home in Cambridge. Crowley took Gates into custody, accusing him of disorderly conduct in his protesting of police behavior, which sparked a national uproar over race relations.

                                                            AP Photo
At a memorial service Nov. 10, 2009, at Fort Lewis, Wash., Biden salutes a display of guns, dog tags and helmets bearing the names seven U.S. Army soldiers killed in action in Afghanistan.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden is joined by California Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger (left) and Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley (right) while speaking about jobs recovery on Oct. 30, 2009.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden shakes hands with New York Yankee Derek Jeter before Game 3 of the Major League Baseball World Series against the Philadelphia Phillies on Oct. 31, 2009, in Philadelphia. 

                                                            AP Photo
Biden exults as he tells female student athletes at George Washington University how inspiring they are to younger girls, during an announcement about action on Title IX, which provides equal opportunities for female athletes, April 20, 2010. 

                                                            AP Photo
Biden talks to local fishermen in New Orleans on June 29, 2010, as he visits Pomes Seafood distributor, which shut down after the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden talks to reporters May 24, 2011, after trying to bridge the gap between Republicans and Democrats in Congress on how to solve America's debt crisis.

                                                            AP Photo
International Brotherhood of Teamsters General President James P. Hoffa (right) introduces Biden at the union's international convention in Las Vegas on  July 1, 2011.

                                                            AP Photo
Biden celebrates on election night Nov. 7, 2012, in Chicago after he and Obama won reelection.

                                                            AFP/Getty
Biden comforts family members of Newtown school shooting victims while Obama speaks on gun control at the Rose Garden on April 17, 2013. 

                                                            AFP/Getty
Biden embraces breast-cancer survivor Kathy Stokes of Arlington, Va.,  at the Families USA 19th annual Health Action Conference in Washington on Jan. 23, 2014. Stokes spoke at the conference about how Obama's signature health-care law helped her, and Biden thanked supporters of the law and spoke about initial problems with the plan's roll out and how Republicans were trying to repeal the law. 

                                                            AP Photo
Biden reacts to questions about his potential run for president by members of the media as he waits for South Korean President Park Geun-hye to arrive for lunch at the Naval Observatory on Oct. 15, 2015.

                                                            AP Photo
Obama places a hand on Biden's back Oct. 21, 2015, as they and Jill Biden leave the Rose Garden of the White House, where Biden announced he will not run for the presidential nomination.

                                                            AP Photo
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
description: Before a swarm of cameras in the White House Rose Garden and with his wife and the president at his side, Vice President Joe Biden on Wednesday announced that he would not be running for the highest office in the nation – that he was out of time to run a successful campaign and the window “has closed.” With Biden out of the 2016 contest and his role as veep winding down, POLITICO takes a look at his decades-long career in politics and the policy he has shaped.
title: Joe  Biden's life in politics: An end of an era?
